vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/72b12409-0500-404d-b68f-ad6e82dc4625">VOTING</keyword>         <topcClas>Election and campaign studies - Politics</topcClas>         <topcClas>Political behaviour and attitudes - Politics</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The <i>Scottish Election Study, 2007</i> (SES) is a major survey of Scottish voters before and after the Scottish Parliament elections on 3 May 2007. The aim of the survey was to explain the electoral decisions of Scottish voters on both whether and how to vote. The survey consists of three different waves. Wave One consists of the pre-election questionnaire, Wave Two is the post-election questionnaire and Wave Three is an additional post-election questionnaire to explore the problems experienced in the election. <br> <br> The SES was originally designed as a two-wave panel survey, with the same respondents surveyed before and after the election.  Then, in the light of the unforeseen problems surrounding the elections, in particular, the soaring number of rejected ballots, the ESRC agreed to fund a third wave of data collection.  Wave Three was completed in December 2007 in order to explore respondents perceptions of the elections and the problems that arose, and to investigate whether what happened has had a lasting impact on public attitudes.<br> <br> The survey was modeled closely on recent <i>British Election Studies</i> (BES) (held at the UKDA under GN 33066). As with the web components of recent BES, the fieldwork for the SES was conducted over the internet, by YouGov. The post-election questionnaire (Wave Two) replicates the 'election study' component of the <i>Scottish Social Attitudes, 2007</i> (SSA) face-to-face questionnaire (not currently available at the UKDA however previous SSAs are available under GN 33329). This allows for comparison of the results generated by an internet and a face-to-face survey.<br> <br> Further information is available from the <a href="http://www.scottishelectionstudy.org.uk/index.htm" title ="Scottish Election Study, 2007">SES 2007</a> website and the ESRC <a href="http://www.esrc.ac.uk/my-esrc/grants/RES-000-22-2256/read" title ="Scottish Election Study 2007">Scottish Election Study 2007</a> award page.<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>Main topics include:<ul><li>voting behaviour</li><li>attitudes to parties and leaders</li><li>opinions on political issues </li><li>national identity</li><li>constitutional preferences</li><li>socio-demographic characteristics</li></ul></abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate event="start" date="2007-04-17T00:00:00Z">17 April 2007</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="2007-12-24T00:00:00Z">24 December 2007</collDate>         <collDate><br/>Wave One: 17 - 23 April 2007; Wave Two: 4 - 10 May 2007; Wave Three: 12 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd 24 December 2007</collDate>         <nation>Scotland</nation>         <geogUnit>Scottish Electoral Regions</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Adults resident in Scotland who subscribe to YouGov plc as a panel member, 2007.</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Longitudinal/panel/cohort</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>YouGov plc</dataCollector>         <sampProc>Simple random sample; Volunteer sample</sampProc>         <deviat>Wave One: 1,872; Wave Two: 1,552; Wave Three: 1,166</deviat>         <collMode>Self-completion</collMode>         <collMode>Email survey</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>Weighting used. See documentation for details</weight>         <cleanOps>B</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Standard conditions of access</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required and standard conditions of use apply. (2008) \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdValence politics in Scotland: towards an explanation of the 2007 election\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, <i>Political Studies</i>. (2008), \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdCoping with coalitions? Scottish voters under a proportional system\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, <i>Representation</i>, 44(4), pp.301\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd315. <br> <br> Further papers are available from <a href="http://www.scottishelectionstudy.org.uk/paperspubs.htm" title ="http://www.scottishelectionstudy.org.uk/paperspubs.htm">http://www.scottishelectionstudy.org.uk/paperspubs.htm</a><br> <br></relPubl>       <relPubl>   </relPubl>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Description: English</othRefs>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Documentation: English</othRefs>     </othrStdyMat>   </stdyDscr> </codeBook>
